channel.title: [C++] Tutorial 2 (variables)
channel.description:
Welcome back, you need to read tutorial #1 before doing this or you won't understand shit & doing a quick /emo helps. ;-)
I present to YOU a bit of pie, oops.. i mean code [code] short int b = 21; //2 bytes of memory int c = 35; //4 bytes of memory long int d = 2333; //4 bytes of memeory bool e = true; //1 byte of memory float f = 5.3; //4 bytes of memory _ 40 max i think? double g = 33.3; //8 bytes of memory _ 310 max i think?
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) { system("PAUSE"); return EXIT_SUCCESS; } [/code]
If you read above, you see these strange words coming before another random thing and a = sign and some random ;
[b]<type> <name> = <value>[/b] <-- usage
The first strange identifier is assigning a variable of that type! The second strange identifier is assigning a variable a name! The third strange identifier is assigning a variable a value!
you can also use [code] signed unsigned [/code]
signed can represent a positive OR negative value unsigned can only do positive
Lets also try some simple output
[code] char a = "a"; //1 Byte of memory short int b = "21"; //2 bytes of memory int c = "35"; //4 bytes of memory long int d = "2333"; //4 bytes of memeory bool e = true; //1 byte of memory float f = 5.3; //4 bytes of memory _ 40 max i think? double g = 33.3; //8 bytes of memory _ 310 max i think?
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) { cout << "hello world.\n";
system("PAUSE"); return EXIT_SUCCESS; }
and yes, you can define your own types but we aren't discussing that ( yet ;-P )
[/code]
